Week.
Spokesmen from Lazear house
presented a number of specific
complaints relating both to general service and specific provisions for Catholic and Jewish
students. Overall lack of food
quantity, particularly for the
Sunday supper, frequent refusal
Of seconds, inavailability of a
tunafish alternate, and shortage
of silverware were stressed as
particular grievances.
The presentation of these
complaints came on the heels of
the DSRC food committee's report issued on October 27, regarding an investigation of the
causes of "mild alimentary distress" experienced by some 18
students who reported their discomfiture to the Student Health
Service. According to food comMittee chairman Allen Leadbetter, the findings of the Health
Service did not indicate conclusively that the food was responsible for the illnesses.
Concluding the committee report, Mr. Leaclbetter stated: "As
a result of the actions of the officials in the plant manager's office and their demonstrated mutual concern in his matter, it is
the opinion of the chairman . . .
that the actions they take would
be not only competent but sufficient as well."

Higher education is undergoing
rapid and profound changes,
Doctor Eisenhower said, "and a
university, if it is to remain vital
and viable, must respond to
these changes. To assure that
the response is wise and proper,
however, we must keep in sharp
focus the traditions, goals, and
resources of the University. I
fully expect that the findings
and recommendations of this
Long Range Planning Committee
will be of immeasurable importance in determining the future
course of Johns Hopkins."
Dr. William D. McElroy, Chairman of the Department of
Biology and Director of the
McCollum Pratt Institute, has
been named chairman of the
Long Range Planning Committee. A graduate of Stanford
University, Reed College, and
Princeton University, Doctor McElroy came to Johns Hopkins in
1946. Doctor McElroy is a member of the President's Science
Advisory Committee, the National Academy of Sciences, and
was president of the American
Society of Biological Chemists in
1963.
Study Underway
The Long Range Planning
Committee has already begun its
study, according to Doctor McElroy, and will meet at 'east
weekly for the remainder of the
academic year. "It is too early
to say specifically how the Committee will proceed and what
areas it will examine," Doctor
McElroy explained, "but we will
certainly consider, among other
things, the optimum size of the
University, its expansion into
post-doctoral education, its government-supported activities, the
complex relationships between
the various faculties of the
University, the administrative
organization and scores of 3ther
problems and opportunities now
confronting us. In short, we will
reassess the mission and the
future course of Johns Hopkins."

By HOWARD
MANILOFF
A proposal to ask Dr.
Milton
Eisenhower to write Phi Gamma
Delta's national
headquarters
"requesting that they . . . release their chapter . . . from
the
obligation of carrying discriminatory clauses or references
in
their constitution" was
defeated
by a 6-5 vote with one
abstention
at the student council
meeting
Monday night.
John Kloss introduced the
motion on behalf of the YMCA
cabinet. DSRC representative
Dick Bensinger requested that
debate be limited because of
previous council discussion. President John Glascock set a ten
minute limit on the debate.
Kloss called previous Council
action on Phi Gam's clause
"inadequate." He said that by
aproving an organization's constitution, the University is in
effect, condoning that constitution, even when it contains a
discriminatory clause.
Right To Act?
Bob Feibel, senior class representative, noted that "the
question is whether we have a
right to act. I think that if we
want to take action, we can."
Freshman John Blotzer answered objections that the student poll had indicated that students were against Administra tion action by claiming that
"there were enough votes for
action for the Council to act."
Crowell Opposes
Opposing the motion, senior
representative Chuck Crowell
claimed "A fraternity is different from any other organization." He also told the Council
that he thought it would be "a
little unfair to martyr them
(Phi Gam)."
Don Henderson, Honor Commission chairman, maintained
that "it's up to the fraternity"
to solve the problem.
The voting on the motion was:
For (5)—Feibel, Matt Li r.g,
Tony Romeo, Bob Weinberg, and
Kloss:
Against (6) — Crowell, John
Wilcox, John Sanborn, Henderson, Ralph Cann, and Sandy
Cohn;
Abstained—Richard Bensinger.
The voting was deadlocked at
5-5 when Bensinger was called
on to vote. He giggled, said "I'd
like to be a chicken," and abstained. Cohn casted the deciding vote.
"Lack of Guts"
Asked to explain his abstention
after the meeting, Bensinger
said, "just pure lack of guts . ..
It, came up in a hurry, and I
wanted to think about it." .
In other action, the Council
approved Barry Gould as the
junior member of the Honor
Commission and voted down
(5-4-2) a motion to limit campaign funds.

Rosemont Meet

The debate council turned in
creditable performances at two
recent tournaments. At the
Rosemont College Tournament,
the team won six debates and
lost four, placing ninth among
the twenty-six school entered.
At LaSalle College the team did
only slightly worse, winning five
and losing five.
George Miller, a freshman,
won recognition at the LaSalle
Tournament by placing sixth
among the speakers in the
tournament.

DR. CARL CHRIST
... listens to President's talk

The council also sponsored an
informal tournament here last
weekend. Towson State and
Morgan State Colleges sent
teams to compete against each
other and against a Hopkins
team. Towson's team compiled a
record of three wins, one loss
to win the competition. The
Hopkins team split, winning two
and losing two.
Feibel President
Bob Feibel, a senior representative on the Student Council,
is president of the Hopkins Debate Council this year.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, NOVEMBER 6, 1964

review of the freshman play,
"The Happening At Oben's." In
my opinion, your reviewer was
inappropriately arbitrary in his
decision to deal only with the
content of the play and to ignore
the production itself. A critique
of the content was certainly in
order; it is the duty of the dramatic critic to offer an evaluation of any new play. But does
the critic not also owe his own
audience his views of the performance as such? It is customary for dramatic criticism to
comment on acting, design, and
technical aspects of production,
is it not?

As a member of the cast, I
fear I may sound like a candidate for Miss Sour Grape, but
I would prefer to think that I
am raising a valid question. Certainly the author deserves attention (just try to write a play
sometime), but he may as well
have stood up and read his play
himself for all the notice that
was taken of the production. I
hope that in the future NewsLetter's reviewers will be more
concerned with performances
and offer their readers more
comprehensive reports.

Foot In Mouth
The function of a representative has been discussed
intermittently in recent Student Council meetings incident to discussion of substantive matters. Some Council members see themselves as "trustees": they feel
that they must reflect the wishes of the undergraduates.
Others see themselves as "free-agents": they believe that
they can most effectively serve their constituents if they
vote their conscience, even if they must vote contrary
to the wishes of their. constituents.
Whether one regards himself as a "trustee" or
as a "free-agent," he would surely agree that in accepting the responsibilities of office he is honor bound
to give his constituents an effective voice in the Council.
He Must, of course, be sure that his voice and that of
his constituents is recorded by vote. There are times—
when he disagrees with his constituents or when he or
his constituents are personally involved in the
subject being discussed—when he feels he must abstain
from voting. He may, then, withhold his opinion and
his vote out of prudence, but never out of cowardice.
To do 80 would be to betray the trust given him by his
constituents.
We believe that Richard Bensinger, president of
the DSRC and DSRC representative on the Council,
betrayed the trust granted him by the dormitory students by a abstaining on the fraternity motion defeated
by the Council Monday night. The motion was one of
the most significant considered the Council in recent
years. Bensinger's first explanations for his abstention were based on pleas of cowardice. He then later
explained that he really abstained because he needed
more time to think about the motion.
If he did want time to think, why did he not ask
the Council to table the motion for a week. Why,
indeed, did he, after the motion was introduced, tell
the Council that since the issue had already been
discussed for several weeks, debate should be limited.
Limited debate does not seem like a very effective means
of stimulating thought.
Bensinger owes both the Student Council and the
DSRC a thorough and honest explanation for his abstention.

Kudos
Good praise is in order for Sandy Cohn anti Anthony Romeo of the Student Council for their part in
planning and executing last Saturday's Student Faculty
Forum, and for Dean Strider, who played no small
part in determining its nature and direction. Instead of
deteriorating into the traditional gripe session, the session provided increased understanding of various facets
of the Hop by focusing the curiosities of both students
and faculty on selected topics. Students, faculty, and administration looked at things together, instead of from
the traditional prejudices of their respective positions.
Kudos, at last, for those members of the faculty
and administration who were willing to sacrifice a day
off with the family in order to participate in the Forum,
and to all students who braved the imminence of midterms.

A Little Lyric
"Absence from all classes and examinations usually
results in exclusion from the University." JHU Manual
for Urulegraduates
Once upon a time,
in the land of JHU,
There was an undergraduate,
For a whole semester through,
Who never missed a sports event
Or dances in the gym,
And even passed his mid-terms,
Though the margin had was slim.
And the lectures unattended
And the books that went unread
Were far too great in number
For the student who, with dread,
Began to study for exams
When they were almost through,
And alas, he could not he here
On February Two.
But he hadn't seen the Cotton concert,
Any foreign films,
Or heard the local symphony,
Or been to the museum,
And so he mised a goodly deal
He could have had beside
The lack of education
lie took with him, outside.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, NOVEMBER 6, 1964

W.I1-111 Impoverished
By BARRY FARBER
Station WJHU, the so-called "radio voice of
the Hopkins undergraduates" has gone into this,
its thirteenth year of broadcasting hopeful of
improving both its influence and financial status.
The station, which broadcasts on 830 kilocycles,
began its new season under the leadership of
senior president Miles Wolff. As in past years,
the radio outfit remained the largest active student organization with 70 undergraduates participating in positions ranging from disc jockeys to
technicians
The campus network began operations in 1952
in a site in Ames Hall. It presently has its studio
in the basement of the Alumni Memorial Residences. Since its inception in '52, the station has
been beset by financial difficulties with this year
proving no exception. During the summer, a returning member decided to improve the technical
facilities and subsequently installed a new control panel. The installation, however, exceeded the
station's maximum budget by $300. The board of
control is still reeling from that blow (which
has been resolved by obtaining the most advertising since 1955.)
Makes Official Tapes
WJHU has made an active effort so far this
semester to expand its services. It has been designated by COSE to make the official tapes of
all major speeches presented on campus and,
according to station manager Wolff, will present
its complete file of past speeches to the new
campus library. In addition, the station will also
tape all the speeches in the current special freshman series and will rebroadcast them at regular
intervals.

feel that the free publicity we provide for their
releases is worth the small investment. This year,
we have gotten mostly folk albums, although the
majority of the records in our library are classical."
Although the station has a fine collection of
classical recordings, most potential DJ.'s request
rock and roll shows. If nothing else, the latter

Queen of Love and Beauty
By PETER HARRISON
Previous to Lilith, the films
of Robert Rossen have been concerned with the nature and uses
of power and with the effect of
social environment on character. In films like Body and Soul,
All the King's Men, and The
Hustler, plot is ordered and personality is defined in relation to
the pursuit of power; in the
prize ring, in politics, in the
world of the professional pool
player men fight for fame and
wealth and, to the extent that
they lose their humanity, are
chastened by personal loss (the
death of Piper Laurie in The
Hustler) or destroyed by obsession. These films display an
understanding of the posture
and trappings of professionalism
and considerable feeling for
place; for the starkness of dressing rooms, the grime and squalor
of pool halls and cheap hotels,
and the thick atmosphere of the
smoke-filled room.
LILITH

limits of personal formula, and
virtuosity is rare: it is totally
unlike anything Robert Rossen
has attempted before. Adapted

As Lilith, Jean Seberg is excellent. She portrays the complexity and contradictions of insanity with precision and understanding. Making good use of her
beauty, she probes the rapture
and torment of Lilith with restraint. Avoiding the grotesque
and the simplistic, her performance leaves the conviction of
Lilith's essential humanity. Warren Beatty, as the young man,
plays all in one key: extreme
understatement. Effective in contrast with Miss Seberg's complex
portrayal of Lilith's mercurial
changes of thought and feeling,
this style of acting is inadequate
to either passion or anger.
Beatty's performance is merely
characterization, not the creation of character. Peter Fonda
as the young patient who commits suicide is merely adequate:
he speaks clearly and doesn't
look at the camera.

football coach Bob Scott.
The Jays themselves have been
both explosive offensively and
immovable on defense, While
chalking up 240 yards rushing
against W es tern Maryland
Thursday, they limited the opposition's ground - -le to 32 yards.
Dominated First Half
This was the gridders' first
win over Western Maryland in
five years. They completely dominated the first half of play,
opening the game with a touchdown by Jim Calli on their first
drive. The score was on a sixyard run.
Bulling his way over from five
yards out on a fourth-down play,
Tom Schauer added their next
marker early in the second
quarter. Joe Cowan kicked the
extra point.
"Schauer's run proved to be
the margin of victory," stated
Scott as he pointed out the
Green Terrors' fourth-quarter
touchdown and his own team's
inability to score during the second half.
Cites Defensemen
"We got off to a quick start
-and played solid defensively
offensively, though," he went on,
throughout."

play of tackle Art Pienado and
end Gary Cambell. He also commended a strong fourth quarter
defensive stand by the Jays in
which they hit the opposition for
successive losses of ten, eight,
and seven yards.
Five Injured
The gridders' second impressive victory was marred by five
injuries, all to starters. Sidelined
were guards Denny Ferrazzano
and Ray Nunnally, and Bob Carter, Cowan, and Schauer.

Facilities Show Stress On Function

The new research library, more than two years in the
building, will be dedicated tomorrow at 11 a.m. in a
ceremony presided over by President Milton Eisenhower.

The haunting structure that has seemingly risen
in fits and starts on the east end of the Keyser
Quadrangle, was first planned in June, 1956, shortly
after Dr. Eisenhower came to Hopkins. Ground was
broken for the 4.5 million dollar building in June
1962. All funds have come from private and corporate
donors.
The library was designed to give both the present
library system much needed space and to implement
the University's research activities in the humanities,
sciences and social sciences. Placed in what Hopkins
librarian John H. Berthel considers a "central" location, it is easily accessible from either the dorms,
Gilman Hall, or the other buildings of Keyser and
Wyman quads. The new building will be ready for
use in a few days. It will have hours of 8 a.m. to
midnight.
Unity Maintained
Of the library's six stories, each close to football
field length, four and one-half have been placed below ground. This maintains the architectural unity
of the campus which is patterned after the two-story
Georgian design of Homewood House.
As one enters the new library from Keyser Quadrangle he sees the exhibition and display gallery of
the building's top floor. A lounge-lecture room, highfidelity record and F. M. equipment, and a staff
lounge, as well as the library's administrative offices
are also located on this floor.
Central Chandelier
Wide staircases lead around a large, circular chandelier to the floor below. The main entrance, from
Charles Street, joins these stairs about half-way
down. Together a single, broad stairway then leads
onto the main floor.
The circulation desk, a book checker, and the
union catalogue are located around this central foyer.
To the north on the main floor and behind the cir-

culation desk is the main technical services area of
the library. Here books will be catalogued and prepared for the shelves. A service elevator and stairs
also connect this part of the building with the floors
below.
Public Elevators

To the south is located the Documents Reading
Room and the Valuable Books Reading Room. Two
public elevators, located to the left of the corridor,
descend to the floors below. Further down and separated by the main corridor is the Humanities-Social
Sciences Reference and Reading Rooms on the right
and the Science Engineering facility of a similar design on the left.
Each of these reference rooms will have a seating
capacity of 50 persons and is closely connected to an
open lounge at the extreme south end of the floor. The
lounge itself opens onto a sun porch that may be utilized during periods of good weather.
On the floor below, designated Stack Level A, current periodicals will be kept. A Periodicals Reading
Lounge lies directly under the open air terrace on the
floor and, close by, is space for 10,000 individual periodicals. At present only half that number will be displayed.
Enclosed Items
Valuable book stacks, enveloped by wire cages, will
also be stored on this floor with a separate stairway
entering them from the Valuable Books Reading
Room overhead. Selected Special Collections will also
be placed in these enclosed stacks.
The campus photo-duplicating laboratory, a bindery
for the maintenance of the library's books, a loading
dock, a receiving room, and unsorted book storage
stacks will also grace this level. A map room, housing
the University's map collection, janitorial and maintenance areas, the Audio-Visual Department, and the
Fine Arts stacks complete the floor. The audio-visual
area will include the University's collection of records
and equipment upon which to play them. The Fine
Arts area includes a seminar room, office space, a
slide storage, and an art vault.

Stack Level B, the floor below, will house the
Documents Library stacks. The core of the library,
miles of gorgeous open stacks, starts in
earnest on
this floor. Interlaced with the stacks are
numerous
student carrels with individual storage
cages above
them. Along the walls are private studies,
each containing a desk, file cabinets, space for a
portable
typewriter, and separate thermostats.
These are
primarily for faculty members and advanced
graduate
students.
There are also two seminar rooms
and three typing areas (available for noisier "bull"
sessions should
the need for a soundproof room arise).
The south
end of this floor, as on all the floors above
and below, is a lounge and reading area. This end
is the
only part of the library that remains above
ground
throughout the building, and students acquiring
claustrophobia or other ailments in the depths of the
stacks are urged to use the lounge as an
"escape
hatch."
Computer Space
Stack levels C and D contain more free-stand
ing
stacks, student carrels, studies, typing and
seminar
rooms. Furthermore, the north and northeast
sections of the bottom floor (Level D) will
house the
Homewood Campus's computers. This is perhaps
the
most novel feature of the library. A sacrifice of
4,300
square feet of floor space to the computers is considered well worth the price. Both the library
itself,
with its interest in Operations Research, and departments throughout the Campus will benefit from this
centralization. In addition Homewood, the Medical
Schools, and the Applied Physics Laboratory will all
have their computers connected by special wiring
links.
In summing up the new building, librarian Berthel
emphasized that it should not be considered
particularly revolutionary in design, but rather, a reflection
on the current fashions in library planning. "I'm
excited about it," he said, "but this is not a unique
or utopian arrangement. I hope it's as good as
we
think it is."

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE NOVEMBER 6, 1964

NEWS-LETTER

PAGE THREE

Art
Works by Rembrandt, Picasso, and Van Dyke will
be among those displayed in an art exhibit in the
north and south galleries of the new library starting
Saturday and lasting until Nov. 15.

the exhibit will be a Norman Rockwell portrait of
Dwight D. Eisenhower, donated by University president, Milton S. Eisenhower. Dr. Eisenhower is also
donating a work by Diego Rivera, the celebrated Mexican muralist.
Among the many works of interest, Dr. Rearick
points out the three illuminated manuscripts donated
by Dr. Bober, visiting Professor of Humanities, from
N.Y.U. These are of the Beauvals school, and date
back to the thirteenth century. A handsome bronze by
the Venetian, Tiziano Aspetti will also be displayed,
donated by Dr. Truesdel. These works, along with all
others of the pre-twentieth century category will be
displayed in the North gallery.
The modern works will be displayed in the South
gallery, and will include works by Picasso, Lautrec,

Dr. W. R. Rearick, of the Art Department organized
the exhibit, which is composed of works taken from
collections of the faculty of both the Hospital and
Homewood. Dr. Rearick said that the exhibit is the
first of its kind at Hopkins, and that if successful, may
be the forerunner of others.
The exhibit reflects, in Dr. Rearick's words, the
"very good taste" of the faculty, and is composed of
Mainly contemporary works. Only two or three have
ever been exhibited to the public before.
Dr. Rearick predicts that the most popular work in

and Rodin. Dr. Rearick also points out that there will
be a generous display of works by artists from the
Baltimore area.
The exhibit has taken several weeks to prepare,
with the actual collection of works the most difficult
task. Dr. Rearick points out that a great many of the
faculty collect art, more so than at many other schools,
and that his biggest problem was finding out who had
what works to loan.
When asked about the future of the library as an
exhibition hall, Dr. Rearick said that there were no
definite plans as yet, but that it is hoped that a
permanent collection might be established by donations to the University. At the South end of the
building is a sculpture court, and in time enough
sculpture to make it worthwhile is expected to be donated.

Architecture
The new library was designed so that it would
be unobtrusive to the rest of the architecture
In Keyster Quadrangle. Only one and a half
stories rise above the quadrangle level allowing Gilman Hall to remain the dominant edifice on
campus.
From the east the tower of Gilman appears to
rise from the roof of the library as if it were an
appendage. The large glass area opening on to Charles
Street permits a view of Gilman through the library.
The building was designed by the two Baltimore
architectural firms of Wrenn, Lewis, and Jencks; and
Meyer and Ayers.
The architects found a solution to the problem
Of building a hugh structure on campus, without offsetting the apparent architectural unity, by placing
Much of the building under ground.
The library descends five stories below ground
With area on each level about the size of a football
field. There is room for over 1,500,000 books and research facilities such as visual aids and phonographs.
The lower levels of the library were constructed
Using metal pan construction. Cement, in this process,

Is poured over inverted pans. When the cement
hardens the pans are removed from below giving
the ceilings a waffled terrain. The advantage of this
construction method is that it permits the strength
of very thick floors while allowing weight to be
reduced.
The first floor of the library opens into the
quad level with walls rising two and a half stories.
Stairs surround this open area permitting access to
each floor.
The quadrangle level halls will serve as a gallery
to permit a picturesque entryway at the west. Also
on this level will be the library administrative offices
and reception rooms with adjoining kitchens.
As the structure under ground exceeds in area
the part of the building that rises above quad level,
the roof of the lower floors provides a large patio
at the quadrangle. At the south of the library, on
the patio, is a large square hole opening into the
first floor to permit light to enter the reference areas.
The whole south end of the library opens into
a semibowled garden so as to permit light into the

.....

lounging areas. The rest of the lower levels is artificially lit.
An overall view of the building from Charles
Street shows it adjacent to Homewood House, the oldest building on campus and one of the finest examples
of English Colonial architecture in the world. Although the new building, constructed 165 years after
Homewood House, bears much of the same attendant
decorative features, the two buildings are very much
dissimilar.
The gently sloping roof and dormers have been
replaced by a flat roof. The round columns and stairway have been replaced by square pilasters and
walkway.
The new library deviates from the design of
Homewood House more than any other building on
campus, yet it does not completely reject the architectural principles of that structure. The library is
modern with remnants of an old architectural style,
though it is not intended to reflect the old. It is a
monument to efficiency, a modern device that circulates books, and a device that will undoubtedly enable students to research and study more effectively.

PAGE 4

Trensfer
Local transfer trucks are criss-crossing the Keyser
Quadr-ngle for a period of five months as books are
moved from the 50 year-old Gilman Hall library to
the new research library—less than 200 yards away.
The move, which began on Monday, August 17, is
slated to end sometime in January.
The 1,000,000 books, which occupy some 90,000 feet
of shelf space and measure about 30 miles are being
carried one shelf at a time in special packing boxes to
protect against damage.

Funs
The funds for the 4.5 million dollar new library have
been provided by only 250 private and corporate donors
and were raised over 3 1/2 years, an unprecedented
achievement for such a project. No federal or state
funds were used.
In 1958 the University and the Hospital announced
a ten year development program. Of the four top
priority items, one was a new library on the Homewood Campus.
On January 9, 1961 the Board of Trustees, at the
request of Dr. Eisenhower, gave highest place to
the raising of funds for the library. To instigate
this they accepted President Eisenhower's recommendation that one million dollars from the University's
Ford grant be placed in the fund. In addition, the
Trustees themselves each contributed to the fund. All
this underscored the extreme importance the University placed on building the library.
Close Finish
With only 2.5 million of the total sum required
the contract was let for the building. This unprecedented move permitted the building to be completed
less than six months after June 1964, the month the
money was finally raised.
Instrumental in the fund raising was Albert Hutzler, a Trustee and chairman of the Trustee Building
Committee when the library was planned. He has been
a donor to the Hopkins library for many years and a
past President of the Friends of the Library.

NEWS -LETTER
Another Trustee, Eli Frank, Jr.. was chairman of
the Library Campaign Committee. And Dr. Eisenhower
himself did much to make the library possible, assigning unrestricted University gifts to the fund,
letting the building contract at an early date, and
giving the structure high priority on the building
program undertaken by the University since he became President.

Circulation
With the aide of a computer stashed in the ground
floor, a microfilmer on the main floor, and a checker
at the door, book circulation at Homewood will be
radically different from the past.
The Hopkins student long used to scribbling his
name and box number on the book's card, will now
find it impossible. Instead, he will now be issued a
library card of some sort which he merely places on
top of the book(s) he wishes to check out. The combination will be microfilmed (ID plus the books spine
and front cover) at the circulation desk. Then a stamp
with the date due will be stuck on the book. The student may now safely pass through the checker's portals. Furthermore, should anyone try removing the
sticker and placing it on another book it mysteriously
changes color for all to see.
The microfilm itself is carted away by night to the
computers in the floors below. There it is recorded
on magnetic tape. In this way the library will be able
to post printouts of all books in circulation where anyone can easily see if the book he's looking for is
checked out.
Operations Research
This illustrates just one use the library intends to
make of computers. In addition, the whole card
catalogue will be placed on tape. Future and more extensive use of the computer in library management is
actively being studied by a committee on Operations
Research headed by Dean Roy.
The new library will be of national interest with its
proposed investigations in this area. Such things as
putting the public card catalogue on tape so that a
specific book or a whole subject heading may be
printed out with the push of a button may not be too
far in the future. In any case Hopkins intends to be
prepared.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, NOVEMBER 6, 1964

Librarian
Bringing over thirty years of experience to her new
job in the newly completed Johns Hopkins University
Research Library will be Miss Martha Hubbard, presently the head librarian of the Gilman Hall reading
room.
Miss Hubbard, known for her paper airplane flying
ability, who will head up the bibliographic section
and files of the new library, has been with Johns
Hopkins since 1930, leaving only in 1937 to attend the
Pratt Institute for formal training.
In her present capacity, as well as in her new job,
Miss Hubbard's primary role is, as she says, "To get
material for the students. They have to write something and sometimes don't know where to begin. Well,
I'm that beginning."
Her work at present has been more than normally
complicated, by the moving of the books into the new
library from the main library and the many smaller
libraries. A system worked out for getting books out
of the new library during the shuffle actually loses
the books for a while. Getting them to the students
in the midst of this will probably continue, she
estimates, for some time although the last date given
for being in the new building was November 7.
Miss Hubbard first came to Hopkins in 1930 as an
assistant in the Ordering Department. When she returned from her study at the Pratt Institute in 1937,
she was put in the main reading room and has
worked there since.
The shift to the more complex but less "personalized" job of heading the bibliographic section arouses
only small fears. Said she, "I'm a little bit afraid the
new set-up might be somewhat less personal than my
work now. But once you get two people together, even
inside it, I think things will be all right."
Accompanying Miss Hubbard to the new library will
be the newest of the three main reading room advisors,
Mrs. Joseph Lapides. Attendant at Hopkins for over a
month now, Mrs. Lapides too works on the bibliographic files of the library.
The shift to the new library will only continue Miss
Hubbard's past work. Said she, in looking over the
years, "It's been a great career and I've loved it. I've
had such nice associations with everyone—with the
faculty and the students."

By HOWARD
MANILOFF
A proposal to ask Dr.
Milton
Eisenhower to write Phi Gamma
Delta's national
headquarters
"requesting that they . . . release their chapter . . . from
the
obligation of carrying discriminatory clauses or references
in
their constitution" was
defeated
by a 6-5 vote with one
abstention
at the student council
meeting
Monday night.
John Kloss introduced the
motion on behalf of the YMCA
cabinet. DSRC representative
Dick Bensinger requested that
debate be limited because of
previous council discussion. President John Glascock set a ten
minute limit on the debate.
Kloss called previous Council
action on Phi Gam's clause
"inadequate." He said that by
aproving an organization's constitution, the University is in
effect, condoning that constitution, even when it contains a
discriminatory clause.
Right To Act?
Bob Feibel, senior class representative, noted that "the
question is whether we have a
right to act. I think that if we
want to take action, we can."
Freshman John Blotzer answered objections that the student poll had indicated that students were against Administra tion action by claiming that
"there were enough votes for
action for the Council to act."
Crowell Opposes
Opposing the motion, senior
representative Chuck Crowell
claimed "A fraternity is different from any other organization." He also told the Council
that he thought it would be "a
little unfair to martyr them
(Phi Gam)."
Don Henderson, Honor Commission chairman, maintained
that "it's up to the fraternity"
to solve the problem.
The voting on the motion was:
For (5)—Feibel, Matt Li r.g,
Tony Romeo, Bob Weinberg, and
Kloss:
Against (6) — Crowell, John
Wilcox, John Sanborn, Henderson, Ralph Cann, and Sandy
Cohn;
Abstained—Richard Bensinger.
The voting was deadlocked at
5-5 when Bensinger was called
on to vote. He giggled, said "I'd
like to be a chicken," and abstained. Cohn casted the deciding vote.
"Lack of Guts"
Asked to explain his abstention
after the meeting, Bensinger
said, "just pure lack of guts . ..
It, came up in a hurry, and I
wanted to think about it." .
In other action, the Council
approved Barry Gould as the
junior member of the Honor
Commission and voted down
(5-4-2) a motion to limit campaign funds.

Foot In Mouth
The function of a representative has been discussed
intermittently in recent Student Council meetings incident to discussion of substantive matters. Some Council members see themselves as "trustees": they feel
that they must reflect the wishes of the undergraduates.
Others see themselves as "free-agents": they believe that
they can most effectively serve their constituents if they
vote their conscience, even if they must vote contrary
to the wishes of their. constituents.
Whether one regards himself as a "trustee" or
as a "free-agent," he would surely agree that in accepting the responsibilities of office he is honor bound
to give his constituents an effective voice in the Council.
He Must, of course, be sure that his voice and that of
his constituents is recorded by vote. There are times—
when he disagrees with his constituents or when he or
his constituents are personally involved in the
subject being discussed—when he feels he must abstain
from voting. He may, then, withhold his opinion and
his vote out of prudence, but never out of cowardice.
To do 80 would be to betray the trust given him by his
constituents.
We believe that Richard Bensinger, president of
the DSRC and DSRC representative on the Council,
betrayed the trust granted him by the dormitory students by a abstaining on the fraternity motion defeated
by the Council Monday night. The motion was one of
the most significant considered the Council in recent
years. Bensinger's first explanations for his abstention were based on pleas of cowardice. He then later
explained that he really abstained because he needed
more time to think about the motion.
If he did want time to think, why did he not ask
the Council to table the motion for a week. Why,
indeed, did he, after the motion was introduced, tell
the Council that since the issue had already been
discussed for several weeks, debate should be limited.
Limited debate does not seem like a very effective means
of stimulating thought.
Bensinger owes both the Student Council and the
DSRC a thorough and honest explanation for his abstention.

Kudos
Good praise is in order for Sandy Cohn anti Anthony Romeo of the Student Council for their part in
planning and executing last Saturday's Student Faculty
Forum, and for Dean Strider, who played no small
part in determining its nature and direction. Instead of
deteriorating into the traditional gripe session, the session provided increased understanding of various facets
of the Hop by focusing the curiosities of both students
and faculty on selected topics. Students, faculty, and administration looked at things together, instead of from
the traditional prejudices of their respective positions.
Kudos, at last, for those members of the faculty
and administration who were willing to sacrifice a day
off with the family in order to participate in the Forum,
and to all students who braved the imminence of midterms.

A Little Lyric

W.I1-111 Impoverished
By BARRY FARBER
Station WJHU, the so-called "radio voice of
the Hopkins undergraduates" has gone into this,
its thirteenth year of broadcasting hopeful of
improving both its influence and financial status.
The station, which broadcasts on 830 kilocycles,
began its new season under the leadership of
senior president Miles Wolff. As in past years,
the radio outfit remained the largest active student organization with 70 undergraduates participating in positions ranging from disc jockeys to
technicians
The campus network began operations in 1952
in a site in Ames Hall. It presently has its studio
in the basement of the Alumni Memorial Residences. Since its inception in '52, the station has
been beset by financial difficulties with this year
proving no exception. During the summer, a returning member decided to improve the technical
facilities and subsequently installed a new control panel. The installation, however, exceeded the
station's maximum budget by $300. The board of
control is still reeling from that blow (which
has been resolved by obtaining the most advertising since 1955.)
Makes Official Tapes
WJHU has made an active effort so far this
semester to expand its services. It has been designated by COSE to make the official tapes of
all major speeches presented on campus and,
according to station manager Wolff, will present
its complete file of past speeches to the new
campus library. In addition, the station will also
tape all the speeches in the current special freshman series and will rebroadcast them at regular
intervals.

feel that the free publicity we provide for their
releases is worth the small investment. This year,
we have gotten mostly folk albums, although the
majority of the records in our library are classical."
Although the station has a fine collection of
classical recordings, most potential DJ.'s request
rock and roll shows. If nothing else, the latter
shows can boast the most imaginative names and
formats, with names including "The Louie, Louie
Show," and "Pandora's Box," "B.J. the D.J." In
general programming schedule places the rock and
roll shows on first (6:00 P.M.) with the music
type become more subdued as the evening goes on.
Maintains Professional Level
"At the beginning," Wolff commented, "we
tried to set quotas to provide a balance in programming, but we have found that most aspiring
DJ's do not want to play classical. Consequently,
although we seek diversification, our main concern is to maintain as professional a level as
possible in broadcasting. We have also attempted
to eliminate obscenity on the shows.
Aside from the ever-present fmancial problems,
WJHU is hampered primarily by an inexperienced
staff and by insufficient broadcasting range. Its
staff is composed almost entirely of dormitory
upperclassmen and freshmen (50) with only
six members living off-campus. The inexperience
problem arises from the fact that only about five
of the seventy active members have ever worked
professionally on other stations.

The station had planned to cover the last two
away football games from Swarthmore (November
7). and Western Maryland (November 21)
However, the feasibility of doing such broadcasts depends on the stabilization of the financial
situation. Already big expenditures are anticipated
from doing the play-by-play of the spring lacrosse
games at Annapolis and Syracuse.

The campus network transmits on a mere 4 watt
output (this is all the FCC permits) and so
presently reaches only the dorms and the Bradford Apartments. In fact, it cannot be picked up

Queen of Love and Beauty
By PETER HARRISON
Previous to Lilith, the films
of Robert Rossen have been concerned with the nature and uses
of power and with the effect of
social environment on character. In films like Body and Soul,
All the King's Men, and The
Hustler, plot is ordered and personality is defined in relation to
the pursuit of power; in the
prize ring, in politics, in the
world of the professional pool
player men fight for fame and
wealth and, to the extent that
they lose their humanity, are
chastened by personal loss (the
death of Piper Laurie in The
Hustler) or destroyed by obsession. These films display an
understanding of the posture
and trappings of professionalism
and considerable feeling for
place; for the starkness of dressing rooms, the grime and squalor
of pool halls and cheap hotels,
and the thick atmosphere of the
smoke-filled room.
LILITH
Lilith is a curiosity in American cinema, where successful directors prefer to work within the
limits of personal formula, and
virtuosity is rare: it is totally
unlike anything Robert Rossen
has attempted before. Adapted

As Lilith, Jean Seberg is excellent. She portrays the complexity and contradictions of insanity with precision and understanding. Making good use of her
beauty, she probes the rapture
and torment of Lilith with restraint. Avoiding the grotesque
and the simplistic, her performance leaves the conviction of
Lilith's essential humanity. Warren Beatty, as the young man,
plays all in one key: extreme
understatement. Effective in contrast with Miss Seberg's complex
portrayal of Lilith's mercurial
changes of thought and feeling,
this style of acting is inadequate
to either passion or anger.
Beatty's performance is merely
characterization, not the creation of character. Peter Fonda
as the young patient who commits suicide is merely adequate:
he speaks clearly and doesn't
look at the camera.

Frosh Gridders,
2-0, Play PMC
At Home Today
After ripping Western Maryland 13-8 last week for its second
straight win, the freshman grid
squad seeks another victim in
Penn Military College at 3:00
P.M. here today.
P.M.C. poses as the school to
give the Jays their toughest battle yet. The Cadets are particularly strong on defense with
"two real hard-running backs,"
according to Hopkins freshman
football coach Bob Scott.
The Jays themselves have been
both explosive offensively and
immovable on defense, While
chalking up 240 yards rushing
against W es tern Maryland
Thursday, they limited the opposition's ground - -le to 32 yards.
Dominated First Half
This was the gridders' first
win over Western Maryland in
five years. They completely dominated the first half of play,
opening the game with a touchdown by Jim Calli on their first
drive. The score was on a sixyard run.
Bulling his way over from five
yards out on a fourth-down play,
Tom Schauer added their next
marker early in the second
quarter. Joe Cowan kicked the
extra point.
"Schauer's run proved to be
the margin of victory," stated
Scott as he pointed out the
Green Terrors' fourth-quarter
touchdown and his own team's
inability to score during the second half.
Cites Defensemen
"We got off to a quick start
-and played solid defensively
offensively, though," he went on,
throughout."
Scott specifically cited the
play of tackle Art Pienado and
end Gary Cambell. He also commended a strong fourth quarter
defensive stand by the Jays in
which they hit the opposition for
successive losses of ten, eight,
and seven yards.
Five Injured
The gridders' second impressive victory was marred by five
injuries, all to starters. Sidelined
were guards Denny Ferrazzano
and Ray Nunnally, and Bob Carter, Cowan, and Schauer.

Facilities Show Stress On Function

The new research library, more than two years in the
building, will be dedicated tomorrow at 11 a.m. in a
ceremony presided over by President Milton Eisenhower.

The haunting structure that has seemingly risen
in fits and starts on the east end of the Keyser
Quadrangle, was first planned in June, 1956, shortly
after Dr. Eisenhower came to Hopkins. Ground was
broken for the 4.5 million dollar building in June
1962. All funds have come from private and corporate
donors.
The library was designed to give both the present
library system much needed space and to implement
the University's research activities in the humanities,
sciences and social sciences. Placed in what Hopkins
librarian John H. Berthel considers a "central" location, it is easily accessible from either the dorms,
Gilman Hall, or the other buildings of Keyser and
Wyman quads. The new building will be ready for
use in a few days. It will have hours of 8 a.m. to
midnight.
Unity Maintained
Of the library's six stories, each close to football
field length, four and one-half have been placed below ground. This maintains the architectural unity
of the campus which is patterned after the two-story
Georgian design of Homewood House.
As one enters the new library from Keyser Quadrangle he sees the exhibition and display gallery of
the building's top floor. A lounge-lecture room, highfidelity record and F. M. equipment, and a staff
lounge, as well as the library's administrative offices
are also located on this floor.
Central Chandelier
Wide staircases lead around a large, circular chandelier to the floor below. The main entrance, from
Charles Street, joins these stairs about half-way
down. Together a single, broad stairway then leads
onto the main floor.
The circulation desk, a book checker, and the
union catalogue are located around this central foyer.
To the north on the main floor and behind the cir-

culation desk is the main technical services area of
the library. Here books will be catalogued and prepared for the shelves. A service elevator and stairs
also connect this part of the building with the floors
below.
Public Elevators

To the south is located the Documents Reading
Room and the Valuable Books Reading Room. Two
public elevators, located to the left of the corridor,
descend to the floors below. Further down and separated by the main corridor is the Humanities-Social
Sciences Reference and Reading Rooms on the right
and the Science Engineering facility of a similar design on the left.
Each of these reference rooms will have a seating
capacity of 50 persons and is closely connected to an
open lounge at the extreme south end of the floor. The
lounge itself opens onto a sun porch that may be utilized during periods of good weather.
On the floor below, designated Stack Level A, current periodicals will be kept. A Periodicals Reading
Lounge lies directly under the open air terrace on the
floor and, close by, is space for 10,000 individual periodicals. At present only half that number will be displayed.
Enclosed Items
Valuable book stacks, enveloped by wire cages, will
also be stored on this floor with a separate stairway
entering them from the Valuable Books Reading
Room overhead. Selected Special Collections will also
be placed in these enclosed stacks.
The campus photo-duplicating laboratory, a bindery
for the maintenance of the library's books, a loading
dock, a receiving room, and unsorted book storage
stacks will also grace this level. A map room, housing
the University's map collection, janitorial and maintenance areas, the Audio-Visual Department, and the
Fine Arts stacks complete the floor. The audio-visual
area will include the University's collection of records
and equipment upon which to play them. The Fine
Arts area includes a seminar room, office space, a
slide storage, and an art vault.

Stack Level B, the floor below, will house the
Documents Library stacks. The core of the library,
miles of gorgeous open stacks, starts in
earnest on
this floor. Interlaced with the stacks are
numerous
student carrels with individual storage
cages above
them. Along the walls are private studies,
each containing a desk, file cabinets, space for a
portable
typewriter, and separate thermostats.
These are
primarily for faculty members and advanced
graduate
students.
There are also two seminar rooms
and three typing areas (available for noisier "bull"
sessions should
the need for a soundproof room arise).
The south
end of this floor, as on all the floors above
and below, is a lounge and reading area. This end
is the
only part of the library that remains above
ground
throughout the building, and students acquiring
claustrophobia or other ailments in the depths of the
stacks are urged to use the lounge as an
"escape
hatch."
Computer Space
Stack levels C and D contain more free-stand
ing
stacks, student carrels, studies, typing and
seminar
rooms. Furthermore, the north and northeast
sections of the bottom floor (Level D) will
house the
Homewood Campus's computers. This is perhaps
the
most novel feature of the library. A sacrifice of
4,300
square feet of floor space to the computers is considered well worth the price. Both the library
itself,
with its interest in Operations Research, and departments throughout the Campus will benefit from this
centralization. In addition Homewood, the Medical
Schools, and the Applied Physics Laboratory will all
have their computers connected by special wiring
links.
In summing up the new building, librarian Berthel
emphasized that it should not be considered
particularly revolutionary in design, but rather, a reflection
on the current fashions in library planning. "I'm
excited about it," he said, "but this is not a unique
or utopian arrangement. I hope it's as good as
we
think it is."

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE NOVEMBER 6, 1964

NEWS-LETTER

PAGE THREE

Art
Works by Rembrandt, Picasso, and Van Dyke will
be among those displayed in an art exhibit in the
north and south galleries of the new library starting
Saturday and lasting until Nov. 15.

the exhibit will be a Norman Rockwell portrait of
Dwight D. Eisenhower, donated by University president, Milton S. Eisenhower. Dr. Eisenhower is also
donating a work by Diego Rivera, the celebrated Mexican muralist.
Among the many works of interest, Dr. Rearick
points out the three illuminated manuscripts donated
by Dr. Bober, visiting Professor of Humanities, from
N.Y.U. These are of the Beauvals school, and date
back to the thirteenth century. A handsome bronze by
the Venetian, Tiziano Aspetti will also be displayed,
donated by Dr. Truesdel. These works, along with all
others of the pre-twentieth century category will be
displayed in the North gallery.
The modern works will be displayed in the South
gallery, and will include works by Picasso, Lautrec,

Dr. W. R. Rearick, of the Art Department organized
the exhibit, which is composed of works taken from
collections of the faculty of both the Hospital and
Homewood. Dr. Rearick said that the exhibit is the
first of its kind at Hopkins, and that if successful, may
be the forerunner of others.
The exhibit reflects, in Dr. Rearick's words, the
"very good taste" of the faculty, and is composed of
Mainly contemporary works. Only two or three have
ever been exhibited to the public before.
Dr. Rearick predicts that the most popular work in

and Rodin. Dr. Rearick also points out that there will
be a generous display of works by artists from the
Baltimore area.
The exhibit has taken several weeks to prepare,
with the actual collection of works the most difficult
task. Dr. Rearick points out that a great many of the
faculty collect art, more so than at many other schools,
and that his biggest problem was finding out who had
what works to loan.
When asked about the future of the library as an
exhibition hall, Dr. Rearick said that there were no
definite plans as yet, but that it is hoped that a
permanent collection might be established by donations to the University. At the South end of the
building is a sculpture court, and in time enough
sculpture to make it worthwhile is expected to be donated.

Architecture
The new library was designed so that it would
be unobtrusive to the rest of the architecture
In Keyster Quadrangle. Only one and a half
stories rise above the quadrangle level allowing Gilman Hall to remain the dominant edifice on
campus.
From the east the tower of Gilman appears to
rise from the roof of the library as if it were an
appendage. The large glass area opening on to Charles
Street permits a view of Gilman through the library.
The building was designed by the two Baltimore
architectural firms of Wrenn, Lewis, and Jencks; and
Meyer and Ayers.
The architects found a solution to the problem
Of building a hugh structure on campus, without offsetting the apparent architectural unity, by placing
Much of the building under ground.
The library descends five stories below ground
With area on each level about the size of a football
field. There is room for over 1,500,000 books and research facilities such as visual aids and phonographs.
The lower levels of the library were constructed
Using metal pan construction. Cement, in this process,

Is poured over inverted pans. When the cement
hardens the pans are removed from below giving
the ceilings a waffled terrain. The advantage of this
construction method is that it permits the strength
of very thick floors while allowing weight to be
reduced.
The first floor of the library opens into the
quad level with walls rising two and a half stories.
Stairs surround this open area permitting access to
each floor.
The quadrangle level halls will serve as a gallery
to permit a picturesque entryway at the west. Also
on this level will be the library administrative offices
and reception rooms with adjoining kitchens.
As the structure under ground exceeds in area
the part of the building that rises above quad level,
the roof of the lower floors provides a large patio
at the quadrangle. At the south of the library, on
the patio, is a large square hole opening into the
first floor to permit light to enter the reference areas.
The whole south end of the library opens into
a semibowled garden so as to permit light into the

.....

lounging areas. The rest of the lower levels is artificially lit.
An overall view of the building from Charles
Street shows it adjacent to Homewood House, the oldest building on campus and one of the finest examples
of English Colonial architecture in the world. Although the new building, constructed 165 years after
Homewood House, bears much of the same attendant
decorative features, the two buildings are very much
dissimilar.
The gently sloping roof and dormers have been
replaced by a flat roof. The round columns and stairway have been replaced by square pilasters and
walkway.
The new library deviates from the design of
Homewood House more than any other building on
campus, yet it does not completely reject the architectural principles of that structure. The library is
modern with remnants of an old architectural style,
though it is not intended to reflect the old. It is a
monument to efficiency, a modern device that circulates books, and a device that will undoubtedly enable students to research and study more effectively.

PAGE 4

Trensfer
Local transfer trucks are criss-crossing the Keyser
Quadr-ngle for a period of five months as books are
moved from the 50 year-old Gilman Hall library to
the new research library—less than 200 yards away.
The move, which began on Monday, August 17, is
slated to end sometime in January.
The 1,000,000 books, which occupy some 90,000 feet
of shelf space and measure about 30 miles are being
carried one shelf at a time in special packing boxes to
protect against damage.

Funs
The funds for the 4.5 million dollar new library have
been provided by only 250 private and corporate donors
and were raised over 3 1/2 years, an unprecedented
achievement for such a project. No federal or state
funds were used.
In 1958 the University and the Hospital announced
a ten year development program. Of the four top
priority items, one was a new library on the Homewood Campus.
On January 9, 1961 the Board of Trustees, at the
request of Dr. Eisenhower, gave highest place to
the raising of funds for the library. To instigate
this they accepted President Eisenhower's recommendation that one million dollars from the University's
Ford grant be placed in the fund. In addition, the
Trustees themselves each contributed to the fund. All
this underscored the extreme importance the University placed on building the library.
Close Finish
With only 2.5 million of the total sum required
the contract was let for the building. This unprecedented move permitted the building to be completed
less than six months after June 1964, the month the
money was finally raised.
Instrumental in the fund raising was Albert Hutzler, a Trustee and chairman of the Trustee Building
Committee when the library was planned. He has been
a donor to the Hopkins library for many years and a
past President of the Friends of the Library.

NEWS -LETTER
Another Trustee, Eli Frank, Jr.. was chairman of
the Library Campaign Committee. And Dr. Eisenhower
himself did much to make the library possible, assigning unrestricted University gifts to the fund,
letting the building contract at an early date, and
giving the structure high priority on the building
program undertaken by the University since he became President.

Circulation
With the aide of a computer stashed in the ground
floor, a microfilmer on the main floor, and a checker
at the door, book circulation at Homewood will be
radically different from the past.
The Hopkins student long used to scribbling his
name and box number on the book's card, will now
find it impossible. Instead, he will now be issued a
library card of some sort which he merely places on
top of the book(s) he wishes to check out. The combination will be microfilmed (ID plus the books spine
and front cover) at the circulation desk. Then a stamp
with the date due will be stuck on the book. The student may now safely pass through the checker's portals. Furthermore, should anyone try removing the
sticker and placing it on another book it mysteriously
changes color for all to see.
The microfilm itself is carted away by night to the
computers in the floors below. There it is recorded
on magnetic tape. In this way the library will be able
to post printouts of all books in circulation where anyone can easily see if the book he's looking for is
checked out.
Operations Research
This illustrates just one use the library intends to
make of computers. In addition, the whole card
catalogue will be placed on tape. Future and more extensive use of the computer in library management is
actively being studied by a committee on Operations
Research headed by Dean Roy.
The new library will be of national interest with its
proposed investigations in this area. Such things as
putting the public card catalogue on tape so that a
specific book or a whole subject heading may be
printed out with the push of a button may not be too
far in the future. In any case Hopkins intends to be
prepared.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, NOVEMBER 6, 1964

Librarian
Bringing over thirty years of experience to her new
job in the newly completed Johns Hopkins University
Research Library will be Miss Martha Hubbard, presently the head librarian of the Gilman Hall reading
room.
Miss Hubbard, known for her paper airplane flying
ability, who will head up the bibliographic section
and files of the new library, has been with Johns
Hopkins since 1930, leaving only in 1937 to attend the
Pratt Institute for formal training.
In her present capacity, as well as in her new job,
Miss Hubbard's primary role is, as she says, "To get
material for the students. They have to write something and sometimes don't know where to begin. Well,
I'm that beginning."
Her work at present has been more than normally
complicated, by the moving of the books into the new
library from the main library and the many smaller
libraries. A system worked out for getting books out
of the new library during the shuffle actually loses
the books for a while. Getting them to the students
in the midst of this will probably continue, she
estimates, for some time although the last date given
for being in the new building was November 7.
Miss Hubbard first came to Hopkins in 1930 as an
assistant in the Ordering Department. When she returned from her study at the Pratt Institute in 1937,
she was put in the main reading room and has
worked there since.
The shift to the more complex but less "personalized" job of heading the bibliographic section arouses
only small fears. Said she, "I'm a little bit afraid the
new set-up might be somewhat less personal than my
work now. But once you get two people together, even
inside it, I think things will be all right."
Accompanying Miss Hubbard to the new library will
be the newest of the three main reading room advisors,
Mrs. Joseph Lapides. Attendant at Hopkins for over a
month now, Mrs. Lapides too works on the bibliographic files of the library.
The shift to the new library will only continue Miss
Hubbard's past work. Said she, in looking over the
years, "It's been a great career and I've loved it. I've
had such nice associations with everyone—with the
faculty and the students."

Fencing, Swimming Unchanged
Fencing and swimming schedules remain unchanged, since
the only scheduled December
match for the swordsmen is at
Lehigh, while the swimming
team's first meet is not until
after the Christmas holidays.
Turner declared that "as of
now, we expect completion of
the wrestling and basketball facilities so that they will be in
use after the Christmas vacation.
For the interim, arrangements
have been made for the teams
to practice at other schools."
Pool To Be Checked
Finally, it is understood that
the new pool will be tested within
the next two weeks. Filling the
pool, to assure that no leaks are
present, is a necessary step before final tiling of the facility
can be begun.

At a meeting two weeks ago,
in fact, of 29 varsity and 21

Is Encouraged
"I am encouraged", declared
the coach, "with the attitudes of
the boys who have stayed out.
Also, we are in good shape for
the future, with the large frosh
turnout, as well as the fact that
only two of the upperclassmen
are seniors."
Since the Hopkins pool is as
yet, of course, unfinished, the
squads work out at Loyola. Practices, which began the week before last, are held four nights a
week. Team members are required to attend at least three
weekly, and attendance, even at
Friday evening sessions, has been
outstanding.
